natural problem:
Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$
natural solution: Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get

draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]

Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "\<exists> x y. (x, y) = (6, 1)"
shows  "(x, y) = (21 / 5, 23 / 5)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "\<exists> x y. (x, y) = (6, 1)"
shows  "(x, y) = (21 / 5, 23 / 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $y = \frac{x + 5}{2}$, find the values of $x$ and $y$ such that they satisfy the equation and can also be represented as the pair $(6,1)$. The final answer is $(x,y) = \left(\frac{21}{5},\frac{23}{5}\right)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and L :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. L x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "dist (x, y) (6, 1) = (LEAST d. \<exists> x y. dist (x, y) (6, 1) = d)"
shows  "(x, y) = (21 / 5, 23 / 5)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and L :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. L x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "dist (x, y) (6, 1) = (LEAST d. \<exists> x y. dist (x, y) (6, 1) = d)"
shows  "(x, y) = (21 / 5, 23 / 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If a line $L$ is defined by $L(x) = \frac{x + 5}{2}$, find the point $(x, y)$ on the line that is closest to the point $(6, 1)$. The final answer is $(\frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5})$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" and "y = 23 / 5"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" and "y = 23 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the values of $x$ and $y$ where $y$ equals one-half the sum of $x$ and $5$. The final answer is $x = \frac{21}{5}$ and $y = \frac{23}{5}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "Euclidean_distance (x, f x) (6, 1) = min {Euclidean_distance (x', f x') (6, 1) | x'. True}"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "f x = 23 / 5"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "Euclidean_distance (x, f x) (6, 1) = min {Euclidean_distance (x', f x') (6, 1) | x'. True}"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "f x = 23 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ and $f(x)$ that minimizes the Euclidean distance from the point $(x, f(x))$ to the point $(6, 1)$, where $f(x) = \frac{x+5}{2}$. The final answer is $x = \frac{21}{5}$ and $f(x) = \frac{23}{5}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "((21 / 5), (23 / 5)) = (arg_min (\<lambda>(x, y). sqrt ((x - 6) ^ 2 + (y - 1) ^ 2)) UNIV)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "((21 / 5), (23 / 5)) = (arg_min (\<lambda>(x, y). sqrt ((x - 6) ^ 2 + (y - 1) ^ 2)) UNIV)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the point $(x, y)$ that minimizes the distance to the point $(6, 1)$. The function $y$ is defined as $y = \frac{x+5}{2}$. The answer is $(\frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5})$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "\<exists>x y. (x,y) = (21/5, 23/5) \<and> (\<forall>x' y'. y' = (x' + 5) / 2 \<longrightarrow> (x - 6)^2 + (y - 1)^2 \<le> (x' - 6)^2 + (y' - 1)^2)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "\<exists>x y. (x,y) = (21/5, 23/5) \<and> (\<forall>x' y'. y' = (x' + 5) / 2 \<longrightarrow> (x - 6)^2 + (y - 1)^2 \<le> (x' - 6)^2 + (y' - 1)^2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find a pair of real numbers $(x, y)$ such that $y = \frac{x + 5}{2}$ and $(x, y) = (\frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5})$. Furthermore, for any other pair of real numbers $(x', y')$ that also satisfy $y' = \frac{x' + 5}{2}$, the distance from $(x, y)$ to the point $(6, 1)$ should be less than or equal to the distance from $(x', y')$ to the point $(6, 1)$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "((21 / 5), (23 / 5)) = (x, y) closest to (6, 1)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (x + 5) / 2"
shows  "((21 / 5), (23 / 5)) = (x, y) closest to (6, 1)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the real numbers $x$ and $y$ such that $y = \frac{x + 5}{2}$ and the pair $(x, y)$ is closest to the pair $(6, 1)$. The final answer is $(\frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5})$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "dist (6, 1) (x, f x) = (LEAST d. \<exists> x y. dist (6, 1) (x, y) = d)"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "f x = 23 / 5"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "dist (6, 1) (x, f x) = (LEAST d. \<exists> x y. dist (6, 1) (x, y) = d)"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "f x = 23 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the function $f(x) = \frac{x + 5}{2}$, find the values of $x$ and $f(x)$ that minimize the distance from the point $(6,1)$ to the point on the line defined by the function. The solution to this problem is $x = \frac{21}{5}$ and $f(x) = \frac{23}{5}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "6 \<in> f ` UNIV"
shows  "(21 / 5, 23 / 5) \<in> { (x, y). y = f x }"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "6 \<in> f ` UNIV"
shows  "(21 / 5, 23 / 5) \<in> { (x, y). y = f x }"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If $f(x) = \frac{x + 5}{2}$, find a pair of values $(x, y)$ such that $y = f(x)$ and $x$ is in the interval from $\frac{21}{5}$ to $\frac{23}{5}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real 
and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "closest_point (6,1) f = (x, y)"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "y = 23 / 5"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line
\[y = \frac{x + 5}{2}\]that is closest to the point $(6,1).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(1,3)$ and $(3,4)$ are two points on the line, so the line has a direction vector of \[\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5)); draw(A--B,red);
 draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--D,Arrow(6)); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); dot("$(3,4)$", D, NW); [/asy] The vector going from $(1,3)$ to $(6,1)$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}.$  Projecting this vector onto the direction vector, we get
 \[\operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right\|^2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{8}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.5 cm); pair A, B, C, D, V, P; A = (-8, (-8 + 5)/2); B = (5, (5 + 5)/2); C = (1,3); D = (3,4); V = (6,1); P = (V + reflect(A,B)*(V))/2; draw((-8,0)--(8,0)); draw((0,-4)--(0,5));
 draw(A--B,red); draw(V--P,dashed); draw(C--V,Arrow(6)); draw(C--P,Arrow(6)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix}$", P, NW); dot("$(6,1)$", V, E); dot("$(1,3)$", C, NW); [/asy]
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \frac{16}{5} \\ \frac{8}{5} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{21}{5} \\ \frac{23}{5} \end{pmatrix},\]so the point on the line closest to $(6,1)$ is $\boxed{\left( \frac{21}{5}, \frac{23}{5} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real 
and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 5) / 2"
and h1 : "closest_point (6,1) f = (x, y)"
shows  "x = 21 / 5" "y = 23 / 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: For the function $f(x) = \frac{x+5}{2}$, find the $x$ and $y$ coordinates of the point on the graph of $f$ that is closest to the point $(6,1)$. The final answer is $x = \frac{21}{5}$ and $y = \frac{23}{5}$.
